metadata.title: Modeling Market Crashes using Physics | by Marco Tavora Ph.D. | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: There were many market crashes in history (see this list). Important examples include the crash in 1929, known as the “Great Crash” (see below): Recently, markets have plunged amid coronavirus fears…

all_paragraphs: There were many market crashes in history (see this list). Important examples include the crash in 1929, known as the “Great Crash” (see below):
Recently, markets have plunged amid coronavirus fears, the worst crash since the 2008 financial crisis:

Crashes are examples of rare events. As will be shown here following mostly Paul and Baschnagel, crashes are much more likely to happen than the usual Gaussian or Lévy distributions can account for. See below a simultaneous plot of both distributions.
Taking into consideration crashes, the behavior of markets can be divided into qualitatively distinct phases:

This change of behavior will be compared with a phenomenon known in physics for many years: phase transitions. In phase transitions, there are critical points where several physical quantities diverge. These points will be compared to market crashes.

As discussed in detail in a previous article (see link below), the distribution of stock returns is more similar to a Lévy distribution than to a Gaussian distribution. The former has fat tails and is more effective at predicting crashes and other types of rare events. It is intuitive to suppose that a crash samples the very far edge of the tails (which are identified with extreme fluctuations).
Following Paul and Baschnagel we will simulate the stock price process S(t) as a truncated drift-free Lévy flight (see above a comparison between a Lévy flight and the Brownian motion).
Recalling the article above, the truncated Lévy distribution is obtained by truncating the tails of the usual Lévy distribution using a cutoff parameter such as
where N is a normalization constant. The figure below illustrates the truncated Lévy distribution together with the standard Lévy distribution.

According to Stanley and Mantegna the central part of the distribution, which will be denoted by p(l), where l is a price fluctuation, is well approximated by a Lévy distribution with exponent α = 1.4 for l < 6σ where σ is the standard deviation of the distribution (the parameter α characterizes the behavior at large l). One can generate Lévy increments following the algorithm in this paper:
If the distribution is symmetric with exponent α different from 1 the flight becomes:
Eq. 3 is a Lévy flight for a symmetric distribution where:
Note that the presence of the cutoff makes all the moments of p(l) finite. Furthermore, S(t→ ∞) approaches a Brownian motion.
Let us first define the maximal value function M(t) of some stochastic process x(t):
To determine the distribution of M(t) we need to define a stopping time T. If one assumes that the process stops when x(t) reaches some number a for the first time, we can define:
One can show (see Paul and Baschnagel) that the probability density of the maximum M(t), or maximal excursion, for a standard Brownian motion is:
This result is crucial when estimating the risks of financial markets.

With our choice of parameters in Eqs. 1 and 2, the Gaussian behavior of the extreme events is attained after approximately 100 steps of the Lévy process. In other words, the non-Gaussian character of the price fluctuations is lost quickly.

DrawdownsOne can also measure extreme events using the distribution of drawdowns. A drawdown is the percentage decrease from a relative maximum to the next relative minimum in the price time series. Note that the drawdown methodology circumvents the fixed time horizon problem that happens in the analysis of the distribution of extreme excursions (since it averages over distinct time delays that occur between the extremes).

Now, in Fig. 8, observe the two regimes found in the DJI. For D < 15% Paul and Baschnagel fit well an exponential. However, a comparison of both figures shows that the frequency of drawdowns D on the ~30 % level is higher by a factor of about 10 for the DJI versus the data from the simulation. The simulation data predicts a probability of drawdowns much higher.

Based on the data, a conjecture was made (as mentioned in the introduction) that these rare events are not merely outliers in the “normal” statistics, but instead, they indicate a switch between two regimes: one regime with “normal” dynamics and another regime characterized by immense fluctuations.

Consider the following two crashes in Fig. 9. They show the daily closing quotations of the DJIA near the crashes of 1929 and 1987. We notice that both price series progressively increase in steps before the crash. These steps are oscillations with an increasingly small period that vanishes approaching the actual crash (in other words, the steps get shorter as the moment of the crash is approached). This behavior seems to be a precursor to crashes.
Furthermore, the drop in price has a magnitude that indicates that they are not just rare statistical fluctuations of ‘normal’ price series.

When a crash is approaching, an enormous quantity of traders spontaneously decides to sell their stocks (there is a kind of “cooperativity”) shaking the liquidity of the market. The non-matching demand causes the prices to drop and the market enters a non-equilibrium state. What seems to occur is that the traders develop correlations among them and that triggers the subsequent crash.

In thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, an extremely similar phenomenon happens when the system approaches what is called a critical point of the system. In this article, the authors build a simple model to provide this link between the behavior of markets and thermodynamics.
The Cont-Bouchaud ModelConsider N(t) traders in the market with the same average trading volume. The trader i can either:
The supply-demand difference is then given by:
Usually, in a market, traders ‘interact’ with one another. This interaction occurs in two different ways:

As this interaction causes two traders to adopt a common strategy (they either buy, sell, or remain inactive), a so-called “bond” is created between them. The probability of the creation of a bond is:

which is a small quantity given that N(t) >>1. The parameter b measures the readiness of a trader to interact with his colleagues. The next step is to connect each of the two traders randomly generating clusters, each with a different view regarding their activity.
Clusters of traders where ϕ(c)=+1 or -1 contains traders with active positions and the clusters with ϕ(c)=0 contain inactive traders. See Fig. 10.
The sum in Eq. 7 can be rewritten as a sum over the N(c) clusters:
where s(c) is the size of each cluster. Now, we will borrow some results from percolation theory,
according to which the cluster-size probability distribution of an infinite-range bond percolation model is

which is valid for b approximately 1. The value b=1 is the percolation threshold and finite clusters have b<1. When b=1 a single cluster emerges and percolates through the full system. This is an example of a critical phenomenon where strong temporal correlations generate a different dynamic regime. Percolation occurs when all traders are connected (on average). If b > 1, more traders enter the cluster, which starts to control the overall behavior. If the members of this all-spanning cluster decide to sell, the new dynamics generates the crash. We must have b <1 to evade such a scenario. However, we must remember that b must stay close to one. Otherwise, the preservation of the truncated Lévy behavior is ruined.What seems to happen is that the intrinsic market dynamics is what keeps b close to 1. The nature of the market is supposed to be such that it drives the system towards b ≈ 1 and keeps it in the critical region in periods of “normal” behavior. Now, physics is full of systems that display such behavior. Many models progressively evolve towards a dynamical attractor without any external control (such as temperature), and when they are close to it, they behave critically, exhibiting power laws and fat-tailed pdfs. The analogy here is precise since it is the dynamics of the system itself that takes it towards the critical point. This is called self-organized criticality.
The model we examined, therefore, considers the stock market as a self-organizing critical system!
My Github and personal website www.marcotavora.me have some other interesting material both about finance and other topics such as mathematics, data science, and physics. Check them out!
Theoretical physicist, data scientist, and scientific writer.
